note.p: The Importance of Being Earnest was first performed on Valentine's Day, 1895. At this time, Wilde was in a relationship with poet and journalist Lord Alfred Douglas (Bosie), then 17 years of age, which enraged his father, the Marquess of Queensbury. The Marquess frequently harrassed Wilde in public, naming him a "sodomite," and Wilde--against the advice of friends and legal counsel--sued him for libel. Wilde lost the libel case, and he was then himself sued by Queensbury on charges of "gross indecency" under Section 11 of the Criminal Law Amendment Act of 1885, which was meant to protect young women under the age of 16 from sexual assault. Same-sex sodomy was only decriminalized in England in 1967. Wilde was found guilty, after several trials, and sentenced to two years of hard labor in prison, which he served from 1895 to 1897. This was the maximum sentence for the charge. Wilde wrote De Profunduswhile in prison; it was published in 1905, after his death. Wilde died in Paris in 1900, shortly after his release, never to return to either Ireland or Great Britain. On the premiere of Earnest, Queensbury had planned to pepper the stage with rotten vegetables, but the plot was avoided and the play opened successfully and secured Wilde's artistic status even as he went to prison. The first edition of the play, which we use for this digital edition, was printed in 1899--Wilde's authorship is not noted on the titlepage, or anywhere else in the text, though another small printing of a signed limited edition bearing the author's name was released later in the same year.

This digital edition was produced during a one-day edit-a-thon with partners at George Mason University and The University of Virginia, held on July 25, 2024. Facsimile page images, courtesy of the Small Special Collections Library at The University of Virginia, show that this book was number 335 of a small printing of 1000. The transcription was created from the facsimile page images fed through OpenAI by Christine Ruotolo.
We have located stage directions associated specifically with a particular speaker inside the speech tag for that speech, and otherwise, outside. Em dashes have been replaced with two hyphens.

div.head:
LONDON: ST. JAMES'S THEATRE
Lessee and Manager: Mr. George Alexander
February 14th, 1895

div.stage: SCENE--Morning-room in Algernon's flat in Half Moon Street. The room is luxuriously and artistically furnished. The sound of a piano is heard in the adjoining room. [Lane is arranging afternoon tea on the table, and after the music has ceased, Algernon enters.]

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Did you hear what I was playing, Lane?

sp.speaker: LANE
sp.l: I didn't think it polite to listen, sir.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: I'm sorry for that, for your sake. I don't play accurately--anyone can play accurately--but I play with wonderful expression. As far as the piano is concerned, sentiment is my forte. I keep science for Life.

sp.speaker: LANE
sp.l: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: And, speaking of the science of Life, have you got the cucumber sandwiches cut for Lady Bracknell?

sp.speaker: LANE
sp.l: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: [Inspects them, takes two, and sits down on the sofa.] Oh! . . . by the way, Lane, I see from your book that on Thursday night, when Lord Shoreman and Mr. Worthing were dining with me, eight bottles of champagne are entered as having been consumed.

sp.speaker: LANE
sp.l: Yes, sir; eight bottles and a pint.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Why is it that at a bachelor's establishment the servants invariably drink the champagne? I ask merely for information.

sp.speaker: LANE
sp.l: I attribute it to the superior quality of the wine, sir. I have often observed that in married households the champagne is rarely of a first-rate brand.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Good Heavens! Is marriage so demoralizing as that?

sp.speaker: LANE
sp.l: I believe it is a very pleasant state, sir. I have had very little experience of it myself up to the present. I have only been married once. That was in consequence of a misunderstanding between myself and a young person.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: [Languidly.] I don’t know that I am much interested in your family life, Lane.

sp.speaker: LANE
sp.l: No, sir; it is not a very interesting subject. I never think of it myself.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Very natural, I am sure. That will do, Lane, thank you.

sp.speaker: LANE
sp.l: Thank you, sir.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Lane's views on marriage seem somewhat lax. Really, if the lower orders don’t set us a good example, what on earth is the use of them? They seem, as a class, to have absolutely no sense of moral responsibility.

sp.speaker: LANE
sp.l: Mr. Ernest Worthing.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: How are you, my dear Ernest? What brings you up to town?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Oh, pleasure, pleasure! What else should bring one anywhere? Eating as usual, I see, Algy!

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: [Stiffly.] I believe it is customary in good society to take some slight refreshment at five o’clock. Where have you been since last Thursday?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: [Sitting down on the sofa.] In the country.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: What on earth do you do there?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: [Pulling off his gloves.] When one is in town one amuses oneself. When one is in the country one amuses other people. It is excessively boring.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: And who are the people you amuse?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: [Airily.] Oh, neighbours, neighbours.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Got nice neighbours in your part of Shropshire?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Perfectly horrid! Never speak to one of them.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: How immensely you must amuse them! [Goes over and takes sandwich.] By the way, Shropshire is your county, is it not?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Eh? Shropshire? Yes, of course. Hallo! Why all these cups? Why cucumber sandwiches? Why such reckless extravagance in one so young? Who is coming to tea?

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Oh! merely Aunt Augusta and Gwendolen.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: How perfectly delightful!

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Yes, that is all very well; but I am afraid Aunt Augusta won’t quite approve of your being here.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: May I ask why?

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: My dear fellow, the way you flirt with Gwendolen is perfectly disgraceful. It is almost as bad as the way Gwendolen flirts with you.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: I am in love with Gwendolen. I have come up to town expressly to propose to her.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: I thought you had come up for pleasure? . . . I call that business.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: How utterly unromantic you are!

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: I really don’t see anything romantic in proposing. It is very romantic to be in love. But there is nothing romantic about a definite proposal. Why, one may be accepted. One usually is, I believe. Then the excitement is all over. The very essence of romance is uncertainty. If ever I get married, I’ll certainly try to forget the fact.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: I have no doubt about that, dear Algy. The Divorce Court was specially invented for people whose memories are so curiously constituted.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Oh! there is no use speculating on that subject. Divorces are made in Heaven--
sp.stage: [Jack puts out his hand to take a sandwich. Algernon at once interferes.]
sp.l: Please don’t touch the cucumber sandwiches. They are ordered specially for Aunt Augusta. [Takes one and eats it.]

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Well, you have been eating them all the time.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: That is quite a different matter. She is my aunt. [Takes plate from below.] Have some bread and butter. The bread and butter is for Gwendolen. Gwendolen is devoted to bread and butter.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: [Advancing to table and helping himself.] And very good bread and butter it is too.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Well, my dear fellow, you need not eat as if you were going to eat it all. You behave as if you were married to her already. You are not married to her already, and I don’t think you ever will be.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Why on earth do you say that?

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Well, in the first place girls never marry the men they flirt with. Girls don’t think it right.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Oh, that is nonsense!

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: It isn’t. It is a great truth. It accounts for the extraordinary number of bachelors that one sees all over the place. In the second place, I don’t give my consent.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Your consent!

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: My dear fellow, Gwendolen is my first cousin. And before I allow you to marry her, you will have to clear up the whole question of Cecily. [Rings bell.]

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l:
Cecily! What on earth do you mean? What
do you mean, Algy, by Cecily? I don't know anyone of the name of Cecily.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Bring me that cigarette case Mr. Worthing left in the smoking-room the last time he dined here.

sp.speaker: LANE
sp.l: Yes, sir. [Lane goes out.]

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Do you mean to say you have had my cigarette case all this time? I wish to goodness you had let me know. I have been writing frantic letters to Scotland Yard about it. I was very nearly offering a large reward.

div.l: Well, I wish you would offer one. I happen to be more than usually hard up.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: There is no good offering a large reward now that the thing is found.

div.stage: [Enter Lane with the cigarette case on a salver. Algernon takes it at once. Lane goes out.]

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: I think that is rather mean of you, Ernest, I must say. [Opens case and examines it.] However, it makes no matter, for, now that I look at the inscription inside, I find that the thing isn’t yours after all.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Of course it’s mine. [Moving to him.] You have seen me with it a hundred times, and you have no right whatsoever to read what is written inside. It is a very ungentlemanly thing to read a private cigarette case.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Oh! it is absurd to have a hard-and-fast rule about what one should read and what one shouldn’t. More than half of modern culture depends on what one shouldn’t read.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: I am quite aware of the fact, and I don’t propose to discuss modern culture. It isn’t the sort of thing one should talk of in private. I simply want my cigarette case back.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Yes; but this isn’t your cigarette case. This cigarette case is a present from someone of the name of Cecily, and you said you didn’t know anyone of that name.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Well, if you want to know, Cecily happens to be my aunt.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Your aunt!

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Yes. Charming old lady she is, too. Lives at Tunbridge Wells. Just give it back to me, Algy.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: [Retreating to back of sofa.] But why does she call herself little Cecily if she is your aunt and lives at Tunbridge Wells? Reading: "From little Cecily with her fondest love."

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: [Moving to sofa and kneeling upon it.] My dear fellow, what on earth is there in that? Some aunts are tall, some aunts are not tall. That is a matter that surely an aunt may be allowed to decide for herself. You seem to think that every aunt should be exactly like your aunt! That is absurd! For Heaven's sake give me back my cigarette case. [Follows Ernest round the room.]

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l:
Yes. But why does your aunt call you her uncle? "From little Cecily, with her fondest love
to her dear Uncle Jack." There is no objection, I admit, to an aunt being a small aunt, but why an aunt, no matter what her size may be, should call her own nephew her uncle, I can't quite make out. Besides, your name isn't Jack at all; it is Ernest.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: It isn't Ernest; it's Jack.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: You have always told me it was Ernest. I have introduced you to everyone as Ernest. You answer to the name of Ernest. You look as if your name was Ernest. You are the most earnest looking person I ever saw in my life. It is perfectly absurd your saying that your name isn't Ernest. It's on your cards. Here is one of them. Taking it from case. "Mr. Ernest Worthing, B.4, The Albany." I'll keep this as a proof that your name is Ernest if ever you attempt to deny it to me, or to Gwendolen, or to anyone else. [Puts the card in his pocket.]

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Well, my name is Ernest in town and Jack in the country, and the cigarette case was given to me in the country.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l:
Yes, but that does not account for the fact that
your small Aunt Cecily, who lives at Tunbridge Wells, calls you her dear uncle. Come, old boy, you had much better have the thing out at once.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: My dear Algy, you talk exactly as if you were a dentist. It is very vulgar to talk like a dentist when one isn't a dentist. It produces a false impression.
ALGERNON

Well, that is exactly what dentists always do. Now, go on! Tell me the whole thing. I may mention that I have always suspected you of being a confirmed and secret Bunburyist; and I am quite sure of it now.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Bunburyist? What on earth do you mean by a Bunburyist?

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: I'll reveal to you the meaning of that incomparable expression as soon as you are kind enough to inform me why you are Ernest in town and Jack in the country.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Well, produce my cigarette case first.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Here it is. [Hands cigarette case.] Now produce your explanation, and pray make it improbable. [Sits on sofa.]

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: My dear fellow, there is nothing improbable about my explanation at all. In fact it's perfectly ordinary. Old Mr. Thomas Cardew, who adopted me when I was a little boy, made me in his will guardian to his grand-daughter, Miss Cecily Cardew. Cecily, who addresses me as her uncle from motives of respect that you could not possibly appreciate, lives at my place in the country under the charge of her admirable governess, Miss Prism.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Where is that place in the country, by the way?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: That is nothing to you, dear boy. You are not going to be invited. . . . I may tell you candidly that the place is not in Shropshire.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: I suspected that, my dear fellow! I have Bunburyed all over Shropshire on two separate occasions. Now, go on. Why are you Ernest in town and Jack in the country?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: My dear Algy, I don't know whether you will be able to understand my real motives. You are hardly serious enough. When one is placed in the position of guardian, one has to adopt a very high moral tone on all subjects. It's one's duty to do so. And as a high moral tone can hardly be said to conduce very much to either one's health or one's happiness, in order to get up to town I have always pretended to have a younger brother of the name of Ernest, who lives in the Albany, and gets into the most dreadful scrapes. That, my dear Algy, is the whole truth pure and simple.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: The truth is rarely pure and never simple. Modern life would be very tedious if it were either, and modern literature a complete impossibility!

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: That wouldn't be at all a bad thing.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Literary criticism is not your forte, my dear fellow. Don't try it. You should leave that to people who haven't been at a University. They do it so well in the daily papers. What you really are is a Bunburyist. I was quite right in saying you were a Bunburyist. You are one of the most advanced Bunburyists I know.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: What on earth do you mean?

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: You have invented a very useful younger brother called Ernest, in order that you may be able to come up to town as often as you like. I have invented an invaluable permanent invalid called Bunbury, in order that I may be able to go down into the country whenever I choose. Bunbury is perfectly invaluable. If it wasn’t for Bunbury’s extraordinary bad health, for instance, I wouldn’t be able to dine with you at Willis’s to-night, for I have been really engaged to Aunt Augusta for more than a week.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: I haven't asked you to dine with me anywhere to-night.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: I know. You are absurdly careless about sending out invitations. It is very foolish of you. Nothing annoys people so much as not receiving invitations.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: You had much better dine with your Aunt Augusta.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: I haven’t the smallest intention of doing anything of the kind. To begin with, I dined there on Monday, and once a week is quite enough to dine with one’s own relations. In the second place, whenever I do dine there I am always treated as a member of the family, and sent down with either no woman at all, or two. In the third place, I know perfectly well whom she will place me next to, to-night. She will place me next Mary Farquhar, who always flirts with her own husband across the dinner-table. That is not very pleasant. Indeed, it is not even decent . . . and that sort of thing is enormously on the increase. The amount of women in London who flirt with their own husbands is perfectly scandalous. It looks so bad. It is simply washing one’s clean linen in public. Besides, now that I know you to be a confirmed Bunburyist I naturally want to talk to you about Bunburying. I want to tell you the rules.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: I’m not a Bunburyist at all. If Gwendolen accepts me, I am going to kill my brother, indeed I think I’ll kill him in any case. Cecily is a little too much interested in him. It is rather a bore. So I am going to get rid of Ernest. And I strongly advise you to do the same with Mr. . . . with your invalid friend who has the absurd name.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l:
Nothing will induce me to part with Bunbury, and
if you ever get married, which seems to me extremely problematic, you will be very glad to know Bunbury. A man who marries without knowing Bunbury has a very tedious time of it.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: That is nonsense. If I marry a charming girl like Gwendolen, and she is the only girl I ever saw in my life that I would marry, I certainly won’t want to know Bunbury.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Then your wife will. You don’t seem to realize, that in married life three is company and two is none.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: That, my dear young friend, is the theory that the corrupt French Drama has been propounding for the last fifty years.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Yes; and that the happy English home has proved in half the time.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: For heaven’s sake, don’t try to be cynical. It’s perfectly easy to be cynical.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: My dear fellow, it isn’t easy to be anything now-a-days. There’s such a lot of beastly competition about. [The sound of an electric bell is heard.] Ah! that must be Aunt Augusta. Only relatives, or creditors, ever ring in that Wagnerian manner. Now, if I get her out of the way for ten minutes, so that you can have an opportunity for proposing to Gwendolen, may I dine with you to-night at Willis’s?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: I suppose so, if you want to.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Yes, but you must be serious about it. I hate people who are not serious about meals. It is so shallow of them.

sp.speaker: LANE
sp.l: Lady Bracknell and Miss Fairfax.

div.stage: [Algernon goes forward to meet them. Enter Lady Bracknell and Gwendolen.]

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: Good afternoon, dear Algernon, I hope you are behaving very well.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: I’m feeling very well, Aunt Augusta.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: That’s not quite the same thing. In fact the two things rarely go together.
sp.stage: [Sees Jack and bows to him with icy coldness.]

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Dear me, you are smart!

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: I am always smart! Aren’t I, Mr. Worthing?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: You’re quite perfect, Miss Fairfax.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Oh! I hope I am not that. It would leave no room for developments, and I intend to develop in many directions.
sp.stage: [Gwendolen and Jack sit down together in the corner.]

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: I’m sorry if we are a little late, Algernon, but I was obliged to call on dear Lady Harbury. I hadn’t been there since her poor husband’s death. I never saw a woman so altered ; she looks quite twenty years younger. And now I’ll have a cup of tea, and one of those nice cucumber sandwiches you promised me.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Certainly, Aunt Augusta.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: Won’t you come and sit here, Gwendolen?

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Thanks, mamma, I’m quite comfortable where I am.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Good heavens! Lane! Why are there no cucumber sandwiches? I ordered them specially.

sp.speaker: LANE
sp.l: There were no cucumbers in the market this morning, sir. I went down twice.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: No cucumbers!

sp.speaker: LANE
sp.l: No, sir. Not even for ready money.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: That will do, Lane, thank you.

sp.speaker: LANE
sp.l: Thank you, sir.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: I am greatly distressed, Aunt Augusta, about there being no cucumbers, not even for ready money.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: It really makes no matter, Algernon. I had some crumpets with Lady Harbury, who seems to me to be living entirely for pleasure now.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: I hear her hair has turned quite gold from grief.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: It certainly has changed its colour. From what cause I, of course, cannot say. [Algernon crosses and hands tea.] Thank you. I’ve quite a treat for you to-night, Algernon. I am going to send you down with Mary Farquhar. She is such a nice woman, and so attentive to her husband. It’s delightful to watch them.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: I am afraid, Aunt Augusta, I shall have to give up the pleasure of dining with you to-night after all.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: I hope not, Algernon. It would put my table completely out. Your uncle would have to dine upstairs. Fortunately he is accustomed to that.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: It is a great bore, and, I need hardly say, a terrible disappointment to me, but the fact is I have just had a telegram to say that my poor friend Bunbury is very ill again. [Exchanges glances with Jack.] They seem to think I should be with him.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: It is very strange. This Mr. Bunbury seems to suffer from curiously bad health.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Yes; poor Bunbury is a dreadful invalid.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l:
Well, I must say, Algernon, that I think it is high time that Mr. Bunbury made up his mind whether he was going to live or to die. This shilly-shallying with the question is absurd. Nor do I in any way approve of the modern sympathy with invalids. I consider it morbid. Illness of any kind is hardly a thing to be encouraged in others. Health is the primary duty of life. I am always telling that to your poor uncle, but he never seems to take much notice . . . as far as any improvement in his ailments
goes. I should be much obliged if you would ask Mr. Bunbury, from me, to be kind enough not to have a relapse on Saturday, for I rely on you to arrange my music for me. It is my last reception, and one wants something that will encourage conversation, particularly at the end of the season when everyone has practically said whatever they had to say, which, in most cases, was probably not much.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: I’ll speak to Bunbury, Aunt Augusta, if he is still conscious, and I think I can promise you he’ll be all right by Saturday. Of course the music is a great difficulty. You see, if one plays good music, people don’t listen, and if one plays bad music people don’t talk. But I’ll run over the programme I’ve drawn out, if you will kindly come into the next room for a moment.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: Thank you, Algernon. It is very thoughtful of you. [Rising, and following Algernon.] I’m sure the programme will be delightful, after a few expurgations. French songs I cannot possibly allow. People always seem to think that they are improper, and either look shocked, which is vulgar, or laugh, which is worse. But German sounds a thoroughly respectable language, and indeed, I believe is so. Gwendolen, you will accompany me.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Certainly, mamma.

div.stage: [Lady Bracknell and Algernon go into the music-room, Gwendolen remains behind.]

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Charming day it has been, Miss Fairfax.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Pray don’t talk to me about the weather, Mr. Worthing. Whenever people talk to me about the weather, I always feel quite certain that they mean something else. And that makes me so nervous.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: I do mean something else.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: I thought so. In fact, I am never wrong.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: And I would like to be allowed to take advantage of Lady Bracknell’s temporary absence . . .

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: I would certainly advise you to do so. Mamma has a way of coming back suddenly into a room that I have often had to speak to her about.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: [Nervously.] Miss Fairfax, ever since I met you I have admired you more than any girl . . . I have ever met since . . . I met you.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Yes, I am quite aware of the fact. And I often wish that in public, at any rate, you had been more demonstrative. For me you have always had an irresistible fascination. Even before I met you I was far from indifferent to you. [Jack looks at her in amazement.] We live, as I hope you know, Mr. Worthing, in an age of ideals. The fact is constantly mentioned in the more expensive monthly magazines, and has reached the provincial pulpits I am told; and my ideal has always been to love some one of the name of Ernest. There is something in that name that inspires absolute confidence. The moment Algernon first mentioned to me that he had a friend called Ernest, I knew I was destined to love you.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: You really love me, Gwendolen?

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Passionately!

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Darling! You don't know how happy you've made me.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: My own Ernest!

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: But you don't really mean to say that you couldn't love me if my name wasn't Ernest?

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: But your name is Ernest.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Yes, I know it is. But supposing it was something else? Do you mean to say you couldn't love me then?

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: [Glibly.] Ah! that is clearly a metaphysical speculation, and like most metaphysical speculations has very little reference at all to the actual facts of real life, as we know them.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Personally, darling, to speak quite candidly, I don't much care about the name of Ernest . . . I don't think the name suits me at all.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: It suits you perfectly. It is a divine name. It has a music of its own. It produces vibrations.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Well, really, Gwendolen, I must say that I think there are lots of other much nicer names. I think Jack, for instance, a charming name.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Jack? . . . No, there is very little music in the name Jack, if any at all, indeed. It does not thrill. It produces absolutely no vibrations . . . I have known several Jacks, and they all, without exception, were more than usually plain. Besides, Jack is a notorious domesticity for John! And I pity any woman who is married to a man called John. She would probably never be allowed to know the entrancing pleasure of a single moment's solitude. The only really safe name is Ernest.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Gwendolen, I must get christened at once--I mean we must get married at once. There is no time to be lost.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Married, Mr. Worthing?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: [Astounded.] Well . . . surely. You know that I love you, and you led me to believe, Miss Fairfax, that you were not absolutely indifferent to me.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: I adore you. But you haven't proposed to me yet. Nothing has been said at all about marriage. The subject has not even been touched on.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Well . . . may I propose to you now?

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: I think it would be an admirable opportunity. And to spare you any possible disappointment, Mr. Worthing, I think it only fair to tell you quite frankly beforehand that I am fully determined to accept you.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Gwendolen!

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Yes, Mr. Worthing, what have you got to say to me?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: You know what I have got to say to you.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Yes, but you don't say it.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Gwendolen, will you marry me? [Goes on his knees.]

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Of course I will, darling. How long you have been about it! I am afraid you have had very little experience in how to propose.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: My own one, I have never loved anyone in the world but you.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Yes, but men often propose for practice. I know my brother Gerald does. All my girl-friends tell me so. What wonderfully blue eyes you have, Ernest! They are quite, quite, blue. I hope you will always look at me just like that, especially when there are other people present.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: Mr. Worthing! Rise, sir, from this semi-recumbent posture. It is most indecorous.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Mamma! [He tries to rise; she restrains him.] I must beg you to retire. This is no place for you. Besides, Mr. Worthing has not quite finished yet.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: Finished what, may I ask?

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: I am engaged to Mr. Worthing, mamma. [They rise together.]

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: Pardon me, you are not engaged to anyone. When you do become engaged to some one, I, or your father, should his health permit him, will inform you of the fact. An engagement should come on a young girl as a surprise, pleasant or unpleasant, as the case may be. It is hardly a matter that she could be allowed to arrange for herself. . . . And now I have a few questions to put to you, Mr. Worthing. While I am making these inquiries, you, Gwendolen, will wait for me below in the carriage.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: [Reproachfully.] Mamma!

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: In the carriage, Gwendolen!
sp.stage: [Gwendolen goes to the door. She and Jack blow kisses to each other behind Lady Bracknell's back. Lady Bracknell looks vaguely about as if she could not understand what the noise was. Finally turns round.]
sp.l: Gwendolen, the carriage!

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Yes, mamma.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: [Sitting down.] You can take a seat, Mr. Worthing.
sp.stage: [Looks in her pocket for note-book and pencil.]

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Thank you, Lady Bracknell, I prefer standing.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: [Pencil and note-book in hand.] I feel bound to tell you that you are not down on my list of eligible young men, although I have the same list as the dear Duchess of Bolton has. We work together, in fact. However, I am quite ready to enter your name, should your answers be what a really affectionate mother requires. Do you smoke?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Well, yes, I must admit I smoke.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: I am glad to hear it. A man should always have an occupation of some kind. There are far too many idle men in London as it is. How old are you?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Twenty-nine.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: A very good age to be married at. I have always been of opinion that a man who desires to get married should know either everything or nothing. Which do you know?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: [After some hesitation.]I know nothing, Lady Bracknell.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: I am pleased to hear it. I do not approve of anything that tampers with natural ignorance. Ignorance is like a delicate exotic fruit; touch it and the bloom is gone. The whole theory of modern education is radically unsound. Fortunately in England, at any rate, education produces no effect whatsoever. If it did, it would prove a serious danger to the upper classes, and probably lead to acts of violence in Grosvenor Square. What is your income?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Between seven and eight thousand a year.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: [Makes a note in her book.]In land, or in investments?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: In investments, chiefly.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l:
That is satisfactory. What between the duties expected of one during one's lifetime, and the duties exacted from one after one's death, land has ceased
to be either a profit or a pleasure. It gives one position, and prevents one from keeping it up. That's all that can be said about land.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: I have a country house with some land, of course, attached to it, about fifteen hundred acres, I believe; but I don't depend on that for my real income. In fact, as far as I can make out, the poachers are the only people who make anything out of it.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: A country house! How many bedrooms? Well, that point can be cleared up afterwards. You have a town house, I hope? A girl with a simple, unspoiled nature, like Gwendolen, could hardly be expected to reside in the country.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Well, I own a house in Belgrave Square, but it is let by the year to Lady Bloxham. Of course, I can get it back whenever I like, at six months' notice.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: Lady Bloxham? I don't know her.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Oh, she goes about very little. She is a lady considerably advanced in years.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: Ah, now-a-days that is no guarantee of respectability of character. What number in Belgrave Square?

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: The unfashionable side. I thought there was something. However, that could easily be altered.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Do you mean the fashion, or the side?

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: [Sternly.] Both, if necessary, I presume. What are your politics?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Well, I am afraid I really have none. I am a Liberal Unionist.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: Oh, they count as Tories. They dine with us. Or come in the evening, at any rate. Now to minor matters. Are your parents living?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: I have lost both my parents.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: Both? . . . That seems like carelessness. Who was your father? He was evidently a man of some wealth. Was he born in what the Radical papers call the purple of commerce, or did he rise from the ranks of the aristocracy?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: I am afraid I really don’t know. The fact is, Lady Bracknell, I said I had lost my parents. It would be nearer the truth to say that my parents seem to have lost me . . . I don’t actually know who I am by birth. I was . . . well, I was found.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: Found!

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: The late Mr. Thomas Cardew, an old gentleman of a very charitable and kindly disposition, found me, and gave me the name of Worthing, because he happened to have a first-class ticket for Worthing in his pocket at the time. Worthing is a place in Sussex. It is a seaside resort.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: Where did the charitable gentleman who had a first-class ticket for this seaside resort find you?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: [Gravely.] In a hand-bag.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: A hand-bag?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: [Very seriously.] Yes, Lady Bracknell. I was in a hand-bag--a somewhat large, black leather hand-bag, with handles to it--an ordinary hand-bag in fact.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: In what locality did this Mr. James, or Thomas, Cardew come across this ordinary hand-bag?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: In the cloak-room at Victoria Station. It was given to him in mistake for his own.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: The cloak-room at Victoria Station?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Yes. The Brighton line.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l:
The line is immaterial. Mr. Worthing, I confess I feel somewhat bewildered by what you have just
told me. To be born, or at any rate bred, in a hand-bag, whether it had handles or not, seems to me to display a contempt for the ordinary decencies of family life that remind one of the worst excesses of the French Revolution. And I presume you know what that unfortunate movement led to? As for the particular locality in which the hand-bag was found, a cloak-room at a railway station might serve to conceal a social indiscretion--has probably, indeed, been used for that purpose before now--but it could hardly be regarded as an assured basis for a recognized position in good society.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: May I ask you then what you would advise me to do? I need hardly say I would do anything in the world to ensure Gwendolen’s happiness.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: I would strongly advise you, Mr. Worthing, to try and acquire some relations as soon as possible, and to make a definite effort to produce at any rate one parent, of either sex, before the season is quite over.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Well, I don’t see how I could possibly manage to do that. I can produce the hand-bag at any moment. It is in my dressing-room at home. I really think that should satisfy you, Lady Bracknell.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: Me, sir! What has it to do with me? You can hardly imagine that I and Lord Bracknell would dream of allowing our only daughter--a girl brought up with the utmost care--to marry into a cloak-room, and form an alliance with a parcel? Good morning, Mr. Worthing!

div.stage: [Lady Bracknell sweeps out in majestic indignation.]

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Good morning!
sp.stage: [Algernon, from the other room, strikes up the Wedding March. Jack looks perfectly furious, and goes to the door.]
sp.l: For goodness’ sake don’t play that ghastly tune, Algy! How idiotic you are!

div.stage: [The music stops, and Algernon enters cheerily.]

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Didn’t it go off all right, old boy? You don’t mean to say Gwendolen refused you? I know it is a way she has. She is always refusing people. I think it is most ill-natured of her.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l:
Oh, Gwendolen is as right as a trivet. As far as she is concerned, we are engaged. Her mother is perfectly unbearable. Never met such a Gorgon. . . I don’t really know what a Gorgon is like, but I am quite sure that Lady Bracknell is one. In any case, she is a monster, without being a myth, which is
rather unfair . . . I beg your pardon, Algy, I suppose I shouldn’t talk about your own aunt in that way before you.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: My dear boy, I love hearing my relations abused. It is the only thing that makes me put up with them at all. Relations are simply a tedious pack of people, who haven’t got the remotest knowledge of how to live, nor the smallest instinct about when to die.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Oh, that is nonsense!

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: It isn’t!

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Well, I won’t argue about the matter. You always want to argue about things.
sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: That is exactly what things were originally made for.
sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Upon my word, if I thought that, I’d shoot myself . . . [A pause.] You don’t think there is any chance of Gwendolen becoming like her mother in about a hundred and fifty years, do you Algy?

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: All women become like their mothers. That is their tragedy. No man does. That’s his.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Is that clever?

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: It is perfectly phrased! and quite as true as any observation in civilized life should be.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: I am sick to death of cleverness. Everybody is clever now-a-days. You can’t go anywhere without meeting clever people. The thing has become an absolute public nuisance. I wish to goodness we had a few fools left.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: We have.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: I should extremely like to meet them. What do they talk about?

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: The fools? Oh! about the clever people, of course.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: What fools!

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: By the way, did you tell Gwendolen the truth about your being Ernest in town, and Jack in the country?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: [In a very patronising manner.] My dear fellow, the truth isn’t quite the sort of thing one tells to a nice sweet refined girl. What extraordinary ideas you have about the way to behave to a woman!

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: The only way to behave to a woman is to make love to her, if she is pretty, and to someone else if she is plain.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Oh, that is nonsense.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: What about your brother? What about the profligate Ernest?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Oh, before the end of the week I shall have got rid of him. I’ll say he died in Paris of apoplexy. Lots of people die of apoplexy, quite suddenly, don’t they?

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Yes, but it’s hereditary, my dear fellow. It’s a sort of thing that runs in families. You had much better say a severe chill.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: You are sure a severe chill isn’t hereditary, or anything of that kind?

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Of course it isn’t!

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Very well, then. My poor brother Ernest is carried off suddenly in Paris, by a severe chill. That gets rid of him.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: But I thought you said that . . . Miss Cardew was a little too much interested in your poor brother Ernest? Won’t she feel his loss a good deal?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Oh, that is all right. Cecily is not a silly romantic girl, I am glad to say. She has got a capital appetite, goes long walks, and pays no attention at all to her lessons.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: I would rather like to see Cecily.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: I will take very good care you never do. She is excessively pretty, and she is only just eighteen.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Have you told Gwendolen yet that you have an excessively pretty ward who is only just eighteen?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Oh! one doesn’t blurt these things out to people. Cecily and Gwendolen are perfectly certain to be extremely great friends. I’ll bet you anything you like that half an hour after they have met, they will be calling each other sister.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Women only do that when they have called each other a lot of other things first. Now, my dear boy, if we want to get a good table at Willis’s, we really must go and dress. Do you know it is nearly seven?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: [Irritably.] Oh! it always is nearly seven.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Well, I’m hungry.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: I never knew you when you weren’t...

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: What shall we do after dinner? Go to a theatre?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Oh no! I loathe listening.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Well, let us go to the Club?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Oh, no! I hate talking.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Well, we might trot round to the Empire at ten?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Oh no! I can’t bear looking at things. It is so silly.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Well, what shall we do?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Nothing!

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: It is awfully hard work doing nothing. However, I don’t mind hard work where there is no definite object of any kind.

sp.speaker: LANE
sp.l: Miss Fairfax.
Gwendolen, upon my word!

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Algy, kindly turn your back. I have something very particular to say to Mr. Worthing.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Really, Gwendolen, I don’t think I can allow this at all.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Algy, you always adopt a strictly immoral attitude towards life. You are not quite old enough to do that. [Algernon retires to the fireplace.]

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: My own darling!

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Ernest, we may never be married. From the expression on mamma’s face I fear we never shall. Few parents now-a-days pay any regard to what their children say to them. The old-fashioned respect for the young is fast dying out. Whatever influence I ever had over mamma, I lost at the age of three. But although she may prevent us from becoming man and wife, and I may marry someone else, and marry often, nothing that she can possibly do can alter my eternal devotion to you.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Dear Gwendolen!

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: The story of your romantic origin, as related to me by mamma, with unpleasing comments, has naturally stirred the deeper fibres of my nature. Your Christian name has an irresistible fascination. The simplicity of your character makes you exquisitely incomprehensible to me. Your town address at the Albany I have. What is your address in the country?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: The Manor House, Woolton, Hertfordshire.
sp.stage: [Algernon, who has been carefully listening, smiles to himself, and writes the address on his shirt-cuff. Then picks up the Railway Guide.]

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: There is a good postal service, I suppose? It may be necessary to do something desperate. That of course will require serious consideration. I will communicate with you daily.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: My own one!

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: How long do you remain in town?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Till Monday.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Good! Algy, you may turn round now.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Thanks, I’ve turned round already.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: You may also ring the bell.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: You will let me see you to your carriage, my own darling?

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Certainly.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: [To Lane, who now enters.] I will see Miss Fairfax out.

sp.speaker: LANE
sp.l: Yes, sir. [Jack and Gwendolen go off.] [Lane presents several letters on a salver to Algernon.] [It is to be surmised that they are bills, as Algernon after looking at the envelopes, tears them up.]

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: A glass of sherry, Lane.

sp.speaker: LANE
sp.l: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: To-morrow, Lane, I’m going Bunburying.

sp.speaker: LANE
sp.l: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: I shall probably not be back till Monday. You can put up my dress clothes, my smoking jacket, and all the Bunbury suits...

sp.speaker: LANE
sp.l: Yes, sir. [Handing sherry.]

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: I hope to-morrow will be a fine day, Lane.

sp.speaker: LANE
sp.l: It never is, sir.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Lane, you're a perfect pessimist.

sp.speaker: LANE
sp.l: I do my best to give satisfaction, sir.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: There’s a sensible, intellectual girl! the only girl I ever cared for in my life. [Algernon is laughing immoderately.] What on earth are you so amused at?

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Oh, I’m a little anxious about poor Bunbury, that is all.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: If you don’t take care, your friend Bunbury will get you into a serious scrape some day.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: I love scrapes. They are the only things that are never serious.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Oh, that’s nonsense, Algy. You never talk anything but nonsense.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Nobody ever does.

div.stage: [Jack looks indignantly at him, and leaves the room. Algernon lights a cigarette, reads his shirt-cuff, and smiles.]

SCENE--Garden at the Manor House. A flight of gray stone steps leads up to the house. The garden, an old-fashioned one, full of roses. Time of year, July. Basket chairs, and a table covered with books, are set under a large yew tree.
[Miss Prism discovered seated at the table. Cecily is at the back watering flowers.]

sp.speaker: MISS PRISM
sp.l: [Calling.] Cecily, Cecily! Surely such a utilitarian occupation as the watering of flowers is rather Moulton’s duty than yours? Especially at a moment when intellectual pleasures await you. Your German grammar is on the table. Pray open it at page fifteen. We will repeat yesterday’s lesson.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: [Coming over very slowly.] But I don’t like German. It isn’t at all a becoming language. I know perfectly well that I look quite plain after my German lesson.

sp.speaker: MISS PRISM
sp.l: Child, you know how anxious your guardian is that you should improve yourself in every way. He laid particular stress on your German, as he was leaving for town yesterday. Indeed, he always lays stress on your German when he is leaving for town.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Dear Uncle Jack is so very serious! Sometimes he is so serious that I think he cannot be quite well.

sp.speaker: MISS PRISM
sp.l: [Drawing herself up.] Your guardian enjoys the best of health, and his gravity of demeanour is especially to be commended in one so comparatively young as he is. I know no one who has a higher sense of duty and responsibility.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: I suppose that is why he often looks a little bored when we three are together.

sp.speaker: MISS PRISM
sp.l: Cecily! I am surprised at you. Mr. Worthing has many troubles in his life. Idle merriment and triviality would be out of place in his conversation. You must remember his constant anxiety about that unfortunate young man his brother.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: I wish Uncle Jack would allow that unfortunate young man, his brother, to come down here sometimes. We might have a good influence over him, Miss Prism. I am sure you certainly would. You know German, and geology, and things of that kind influence a man very much. [Cecily begins to write in her diary.]

sp.speaker: MISS PRISM
sp.l: [Shaking her head.] I do not think that even I could produce any effect on a character that according to his own brother's admission is irretrievably weak and vacillating. Indeed I am not sure that I would desire to reclaim him. I am not in favour of this modern mania for turning bad people into good people at a moment's notice. As a man sows so let him reap. You must put away your diary, Cecily. I really don't see why you should keep a diary at all.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: I keep a diary in order to enter the wonderful secrets of my life. If I didn't write them down I should probably forget all about them.

sp.speaker: MISS PRISM
sp.l: Memory, my dear Cecily, is the diary that we all carry about with us.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l:
Yes, but it usually chronicles the things that have
never happened, and couldn't possibly have happened. I believe that Memory is responsible for nearly all the three-volume novels that Mudie sends us.

sp.speaker: MISS PRISM
sp.l: Do not speak slightingly of the three-volume novel, Cecily. I wrote one myself in earlier days.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Did you really, Miss Prism? How wonderfully clever you are! I hope it did not end happily? I don't like novels that end happily. They depress me so much.

sp.speaker: MISS PRISM
sp.l: The good ended happily, and the bad unhappily. That is what Fiction means.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: I suppose so. But it seems very unfair. And was your novel ever published?

sp.speaker: MISS PRISM
sp.l: Alas! no. The manuscript unfortunately was abandoned. I use the word in the sense of lost or mislaid. To your work, child, these speculations are profitless.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: [Smiling.] But I see dear Dr. Chasuble coming up through the garden.

sp.speaker: MISS PRISM
sp.l: [Rising and advancing.] Dr. Chasuble! This is indeed a pleasure.

sp.speaker: CHASUBLE
sp.l: And how are we this morning? Miss Prism, you are, I trust, well?

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Miss Prism has just been complaining of a slight headache. I think it would do her so much good to have a short stroll with you in the Park, Dr. Chasuble.

sp.speaker: MISS PRISM
sp.l: Cecily, I have not mentioned anything about a headache.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: No, dear Miss Prism, I know that, but I felt instinctively that you had a headache. Indeed I was thinking about that, and not about my German lesson, when the Rector came in.

sp.speaker: CHASUBLE
sp.l: I hope Cecily, you are not inattentive.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Oh, I am afraid I am.

sp.speaker: CHASUBLE
sp.l: That is strange. Were I fortunate enough to be Miss Prism's pupil, I would hang upon her lips. [Miss Prism glares.] I spoke metaphorically.--My metaphor was drawn from bees. Ahem! Mr. Worthing I suppose, has not returned from town yet?

sp.speaker: MISS PRISM
sp.l: We do not expect him till Monday afternoon.

sp.speaker: CHASUBLE
sp.l: Ah yes, he usually likes to spend his Sunday in London. He is not one of those whose sole aim is enjoyment, as, by all accounts, that unfortunate young man his brother seems to be. But I must not disturb Egeria and her pupil any longer.

sp.speaker: MISS PRISM
sp.l: Egeria? My name is Laetitia, Doctor.

sp.speaker: CHASUBLE
sp.l: [Bowing.] A classical allusion merely, drawn from the Pagan authors. I shall see you both no doubt at Evensong?

sp.speaker: MISS PRISM
sp.l: I think, dear Doctor, I will have a stroll with you. I find I have a headache after all, and a walk might do it good.

sp.speaker: CHASUBLE
sp.l: With pleasure, Miss Prism, with pleasure. We might go as far as the schools and back.

sp.speaker: MISS PRISM
sp.l: That would be delightful. Cecily, you will read your Political Economy in my absence. The chapter on the Fall of the Rupee you may omit. It is somewhat too sensational. Even these metallic problems have their melodramatic side.
sp.stage: [Goes down the garden with Dr. Chasuble.]

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.stage: [Picks up books and throws them back on table.]
sp.l: Horrid Political Economy! Horrid Geography! Horrid, horrid German!

div.stage: [Enter Merriman with a card on a salver.]

sp.speaker: MERRIMAN
sp.l: Mr. Ernest Worthing has just driven over from the station. He has brought his luggage with him.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: [Takes the card and reads it.]“Mr. Ernest Worthing, B. 4 The Albany, W." Uncle Jack’s brother! Did you tell him Mr. Worthing was in town?

sp.speaker: MERRIMAN
sp.l: Yes, Miss. He seemed very much disappointed. I mentioned that you and Miss Prism were in the garden. He said he was anxious to speak to you privately for a moment.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Ask Mr. Ernest Worthing to come here. I suppose you had better talk to the housekeeper about a room for him.

sp.speaker: MERRIMAN
sp.l: Yes, Miss.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: I have never met any really wicked person before. I feel rather frightened. I am so afraid he will look just like everyone else.
JHe does!

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: [Raising his hat.] You are my little cousin Cecily, I’m sure.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l:
You are under some strange mistake. I am not little. In fact, I believe I am more than usually tall for my age. [Algernon is rather taken aback.] But I am your cousin Cecily. You, I see from your
card, are Uncle Jack’s brother, my cousin Ernest, my wicked cousin Ernest.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Oh! I am not really wicked at all, cousin Cecily. You mustn’t think that I am wicked.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: If you are not, then you have certainly been deceiving us all in a very inexcusable manner. I hope you have not been leading a double life, pretending to be wicked and being really good all the time. That would be hypocrisy.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: [Looks at her in amazement.]Oh! Of course I have been rather reckless.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: I am glad to hear it.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: In fact, now you mention the subject, I have been very bad in my own small way.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: I don’t think you should be so proud of that, though I am sure it must have been very pleasant.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: It is much pleasanter being here with you.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: I can’t understand how you are here at all. Uncle Jack won’t be back till Monday afternoon.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: That is a great disappointment. I am obliged to go up by the first train on Monday morning. I have a business appointment that I am anxious . . . to miss.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Couldn’t you miss it anywhere but in London.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: No: the appointment is in London.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Well, I know, of course, how important it is not to keep a business engagement, if one wants to retain any sense of the beauty of life, but still I think you had better wait till Uncle Jack arrives. I know he wants to speak to you about your emigrating.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: About my what?

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Your emigrating. He has gone up to buy your outfit.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: I certainly wouldn’t let Jack buy my outfit. He has no taste in neckties at all.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: I don’t think you will require neckties. Uncle Jack is sending you to Australia.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Australia! I’d sooner die.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Well, he said at dinner on Wednesday night, that you would have to choose between this world, the next world, and Australia.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Oh, well! The accounts I have received of Australia and the next world, are not particularly encouraging. This world is good enough for me, cousin Cecily.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Yes, but are you good enough for it?

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: I’m afraid I’m not that. That is why I want you to reform me. You might make that your mission, if you don’t mind, cousin Cecily.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: I’m afraid I’ve no time, this afternoon.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Well, would you mind my reforming myself this afternoon?

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: It is rather Quixotic of you. But I think you should try.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: I will. I feel better already.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: You are looking a little worse.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: That is because I am hungry.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: How thoughtless of me. I should have remembered that when one is going to lead an entirely new life, one requires regular and wholesome meals. Won’t you come in?

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Thank you. Might I have a button-hole first? I never have any appetite unless I have a button-hole first.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: A Maréshale Niel?[Picks up scissors.]

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: No, I’d sooner have a pink rose.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Why?[Cuts a flower.]

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Because you are like a pink rose, Cousin Cecily.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: I don’t think it can be right for you to talk to me like that. Miss Prism never says such things to me.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Then Miss Prism is a short-sighted old lady.[Cecily puts the rose in his button-hole.] You are the prettiest girl I ever saw.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Miss Prism says that all good looks are a snare.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: They are a snare that every sensible man would like to be caught in.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Oh! I don’t think I would care to catch a sensible man. I shouldn’t know what to talk to him about.

div.stage: [They pass into the house. Miss Prism and Dr. Chasuble return.]

sp.speaker: MISS PRISM
sp.l: You are too much alone, dear Dr. Chasuble. You should get married. A misanthrope I can understand--a womanthrope, never!

sp.speaker: CHASUBLE
sp.l: Believe me, I do not deserve so neologistic a phrase. The precept as well as the practice of the Primitive Church was distinctly against matrimony.

sp.speaker: MISS PRISM
sp.l: That is obviously the reason why the Primitive Church has not lasted up to the present day. And you do not seem to realize, dear Doctor, that by persistently remaining single, a man converts himself into a permanent public temptation. Men should be more careful; this very celibacy leads weaker vessels astray.

sp.speaker: CHASUBLE
sp.l: But is a man not equally attractive when married?

sp.speaker: MISS PRISM
sp.l: No married man is ever attractive except to his wife.

sp.speaker: CHASUBLE
sp.l: And often, I’ve been told, not even to her.

sp.speaker: MISS PRISM
sp.l: That depends on the intellectual sympathies of the woman. Maturity can always be depended on. Ripeness can be trusted. Young women are green.[Dr. Chasuble starts.]I spoke horticulturally. My metaphor was drawn from fruits. But where is Cecily?

sp.speaker: CHASUBLE
sp.l: Perhaps she followed us to the schools.
sp.stage: [Enter Jack slowly from the back of the garden. He is dressed in the deepest mourning, with crape hatband and black gloves.]

sp.speaker: MISS PRISM
sp.l: Mr. Worthing!

sp.speaker: CHASUBLE
sp.l: Mr. Worthing?

sp.speaker: MISS PRISM
sp.l: This is indeed a surprise. We did not look for you till Monday afternoon.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.stage: [Shakes Miss Prism’s hand in a tragic manner.]
sp.l: I have returned sooner than I expected. Dr. Chasuble, I hope you are well?

sp.speaker: CHASUBLE
sp.l: Dear Mr. Worthing, I trust this garb of woe does not betoken some terrible calamity?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: My brother.

sp.speaker: MISS PRISM
sp.l: More shameful debts and extravagance?

sp.speaker: CHASUBLE
sp.l: Still leading his life of pleasure?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Dead!

sp.speaker: CHASUBLE
sp.l: Your brother Ernest dead?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Quite dead.

sp.speaker: MISS PRISM
sp.l: What a lesson for him! I trust he will profit by it.

sp.speaker: CHASUBLE
sp.l: Mr. Worthing, I offer you my sincere condolence. You have at least the consolation of knowing that you were always the most generous and forgiving of brothers.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Poor Ernest! He had many faults, but it is a sad, sad blow.

sp.speaker: CHASUBLE
sp.l: Very sad indeed. Were you with him at the end?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: No. He died abroad; in Paris, in fact. I had a telegram last night from the manager of the Grand Hotel.

sp.speaker: CHASUBLE
sp.l: Was the cause of death mentioned?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: A severe chill, it seems.

sp.speaker: MISS PRISM
sp.l: As a man sows, so shall he reap.

sp.speaker: CHASUBLE
sp.l: Charity, dear Miss Prism, charity! None of us are perfect. I myself am
peculiarly susceptible to draughts. Will the interment take place here?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: No. He seemed to have expressed a desire to be buried in Paris.

sp.speaker: CHASUBLE
sp.l: In Paris![Shakes his head.] I fear that hardly points to any very serious state of mind at the last. You would no doubt wish me to make some slight allusion to this tragic domestic affliction next Sunday.[Jack presses his hand convulsively.] My sermon on the meaning of the manna in the wilderness can be adapted to almost any occasion, joyful, or, as in the present case, distressing. [All sigh.] I have preached it at harvest celebrations, christenings, confirmations, on days of humiliation and festal days. The last time I delivered it was in the Cathedral, as a charity sermon on behalf of the Society for the Prevention of Discontent among the Upper Orders. The Bishop, who was present, was much struck by some of the analogies I drew.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Ah! that reminds me, you mentioned christenings I think, Dr. Chasuble? I suppose you know how to christen all right?[Dr. Chasuble looks astounded.] I mean, of course, you are continually christening, aren’t you?

sp.speaker: MISS PRISM
sp.l: It is, I regret to say, one of the Rector’s most constant duties in this parish. I have often spoken to the poorer classes on the subject. But they don’t seem to know what thrift is.

sp.speaker: CHASUBLE
sp.l: But is there any particular infant in whom you are interested, Mr. Worthing? Your brother was, I believe, unmarried, was he not?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Oh yes.

sp.speaker: MISS PRISM
sp.l: [Bitterly.] People who live entirely for pleasure usually are.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: But it is not for any child, dear Doctor. I am very fond of children. No! the fact is, I would like to be christened myself, this afternoon, if you have nothing better to do.

sp.speaker: CHASUBLE
sp.l: But surely, Mr. Worthing, you have been christened already?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: I don’t remember anything about it.

sp.speaker: CHASUBLE
sp.l: But have you any grave doubts on the subject?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: I certainly intend to have. Of course I don’t know if the thing would bother you in any way, or if you think I am a little too old now.

sp.speaker: CHASUBLE
sp.l: Not at all. The sprinkling, and, indeed, the immersion of adults is a perfectly canonical practice.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Immersion!

sp.speaker: CHASUBLE
sp.l: You need have no apprehensions. Sprinkling is all that is necessary, or indeed I think advisable. Our weather is so changeable. At what hour would you wish the ceremony performed?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Oh, I might trot round about five if that would suit you.

sp.speaker: CHASUBLE
sp.l: Perfectly, perfectly! In fact I have two similar ceremonies to perform at that time. A case of twins that occurred recently in one of the outlying cottages

sp.speaker: CHASUBLE
sp.l: on your own estate. Poor Jenkins the carter, a most hard-working man.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Oh! I don’t see much fun in being christened along with other babies. It would be childish. Would half-past five do?

sp.speaker: CHASUBLE
sp.l: Admirably! Admirably! [Takes out watch.] And now, dear Mr. Worthing, I will not intrude any longer into a house of sorrow. I would merely beg you not to be too much bowed down by grief. What seem to us bitter trials are often blessings in disguise.

sp.speaker: MISS PRISM
sp.l: This seems to me a blessing of an extremely obvious kind.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Uncle Jack! Oh, I am pleased to see you back. But what horrid clothes you have got on! Do go and change them.

sp.speaker: MISS PRISM
sp.l: Cecily!

sp.speaker: CHASUBLE
sp.l: My child! my child!
sp.stage: [Cecily goes towards Jack; he kisses her brow in a melancholy manner.]

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: What is the matter, Uncle Jack? Do look happy! You look as if you had toothache, and I have got such a surprise for you. Who do you think is in the dining-room? Your brother!

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Who?

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Your brother Ernest. He arrived about half an hour ago.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: What nonsense! I haven’t got a brother.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Oh, don’t say that. However badly he may have behaved to you in the past he is still your brother. You couldn’t be so heartless as to disown him. I’ll tell him to come out. And you will shake hands with him, won’t you, Uncle Jack? [Runs back into the house.]

sp.speaker: CHASUBLE
sp.l: These are very joyful tidings.

sp.speaker: MISS PRISM
sp.l: After we had all been resigned to his loss, his sudden return seems to me peculiarly distressing.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: My brother is in the dining-room? I don’t know what it all means. I think it is perfectly absurd.

div.stage: [Enter Algernon and Cecily hand in hand. They come slowly up to Jack.]

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Good heavens!

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Brother John, I have come down from town to tell you that I am very sorry for all the trouble I have given you, and that I intend to lead a better life in the future.[Jack glares at him and does not take his hand.]

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Uncle Jack, you are not going to refuse your own brother’s hand?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Nothing will induce me to take his hand. I think his coming down here disgraceful. He knows perfectly well why.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Jack, do be nice. There is some good in everyone. Ernest has just been telling me about his poor invalid friend Mr. Bunbury whom he goes to visit so often. And surely there must be much good in one who is kind to an invalid, and leaves the pleasures of London to sit by a bed of pain.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Oh! he has been talking about Bunbury has he?

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Yes, he has told me all about poor Mr. Bunbury, and his terrible state of health.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Bunbury! Well, I won’t have him talk to you about Bunbury or about anything else. It is enough to drive one perfectly frantic.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Of course I admit that the faults were all on my side. But I must say that I think that Brother John’s coldness to me is peculiarly painful. I expected a more enthusiastic welcome, especially considering it is the first time I have come here.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Uncle Jack, if you don’t shake hands with Ernest I will never forgive you.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Never forgive me?

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Never, never, never!

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Well, this is the last time I shall ever do it.

sp.speaker: CHASUBLE
sp.l: It’s pleasant, is it not, to see so perfect a reconciliation? I think we might leave the two brothers together.

sp.speaker: MISS PRISM
sp.l: Cecily, you will come with us.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Certainly, Miss Prism. My little task of reconciliation is over.

sp.speaker: CHASUBLE
sp.l: You have done a beautiful action to-day, dear child.

sp.speaker: MISS PRISM
sp.l: We must not be premature in our judgments.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: I feel very happy.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: You young scoundrel, Algy, you must get out of this place as soon as possible. I don’t allow any Bunburying here.

sp.speaker: MERRIMAN
sp.l: I have put Mr. Ernest’s things in the room next to yours, sir. I suppose that is all right?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: MERRIMAN
sp.l: Mr. Ernest’s luggage, sir. I have unpacked it and put it in the room next to your own.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: His luggage?

sp.speaker: MERRIMAN
sp.l: Yes, sir. Three portmanteaus, a dressing-case, two hat-boxes, and a large luncheon-basket.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: I am afraid I can’t stay more than a week this time.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Merriman, order the dog-cart at once. Mr. Ernest has been suddenly called back to town.

sp.speaker: MERRIMAN
sp.l: Yes, sir. [Goes back into the house.]

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: What a fearful liar you are, Jack. I have not been called back to town at all.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Yes, you have.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: I haven’t heard anyone call me.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Your duty as a gentleman calls you back.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: My duty as a gentleman has never interfered with my pleasures in the smallest degree.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: I can quite understand that.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Well, Cecily is a darling.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: You are not to talk of Miss Cardew like that. I don’t like it.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Well, I don’t like your clothes. You look perfectly ridiculous in them. Why on earth don’t you go up and change? It is perfectly childish to be in deep mourning for a man who is actually staying for a whole week with you in your house as a guest. I call it grotesque.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: You are certainly not staying with me for a whole week as a guest or anything else. You have got to leave . . . by the four-five train.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: I certainly won’t leave you so long as you are in mourning. It would be most unfriendly. If I were in mourning you would stay with me, I suppose. I should think it very unkind if you didn’t.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Well, will you go if I change my clothes?

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Yes, if you are not too long. I never saw anybody take so long to dress, and with such little result.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Well, at any rate, that is better than being always over-dressed as you are.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: If I am occasionally a little over-dressed, I make up for it by being always immensely over-educated.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Your vanity is ridiculous, your conduct an outrage, and your presence in my garden utterly absurd. However, you have got to catch the four-five, and I hope you will have a pleasant journey back to town. This Bunburying, as you call it, has not been a great success for you. [Goes into the house.]

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: I think it has been a great success. I’m in love with Cecily, and that is everything.
sp.stage: [Enter Cecily at the back of the garden. She picks up the can and begins to water the flowers.]
sp.l: But I must see her before I go, and make arrangements for another Bunbury. Ah, there she is.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Oh, I merely came back to water the roses. I thought you were with Uncle Jack.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: He’s gone to order the dog-cart for me.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Oh, is he going to take you for a nice drive?

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: He’s going to send me away.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Then have we got to part?

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: I am afraid so. It’s a very painful parting.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: It is always painful to part from people whom one has known for a very brief space of time. The absence of old friends one can endure with equanimity. But even a momentary separation from anyone to whom one has just been introduced is almost unbearable.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Thank you.

sp.speaker: MERRIMAN
sp.l: The dog-cart is at the door, sir. [Algernon looks appealingly at Cecily.]

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: It can wait, Merriman . . . for . . . five minutes.

sp.speaker: MERRIMAN
sp.l: Yes, Miss.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: I hope, Cecily, I shall not offend you if I state quite frankly and openly that you seem to me to be in every way the visible personification of absolute perfection.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: I think your frankness does you great credit, Ernest. If you will allow me I will copy your remarks into my diary. [Goes over to table and begins writing in diary.]

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Do you really keep a diary? I’d give anything to look at it. May I?

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Oh no. [Puts her hand over it.] You see, it is simply a very young girl’s record of her own thoughts and impressions, and consequently meant for publication. When it appears in volume form I hope you will order a copy. But pray, Ernest, don’t stop. I delight in taking down from dictation. I have reached “absolute perfection." You can go on. I am quite ready for more.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: [Somewhat taken aback.] Ahem! Ahem!

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Oh, don’t cough, Ernest. When one is dictating one should speak fluently and not cough. Besides, I don’t know how to spell a cough. [Writes as Algernon speaks.]

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: [Speaking very rapidly.] Cecily, ever since I first looked upon your wonderful and incomparable beauty, I have dared to love you wildly, passionately, devotedly, hopelessly.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: I don’t think that you should tell me that you love me wildly, passionately, devotedly, hopelessly. Hopelessly doesn’t seem to make much sense, does it?

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Cecily!

sp.speaker: MERRIMAN
sp.l: The dog-cart is waiting, sir.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Tell it to come round next week, at the same hour.

sp.speaker: MERRIMAN
sp.l: [Looks at Cecily, who makes no sign.] Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Uncle Jack would be very much annoyed if he knew you were staying on till next week, at the same hour.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Oh, I don’t care about Jack. I don’t care for anybody in the whole world but you. I love you, Cecily. You will marry me, won’t you?

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: You silly boy! Of course. Why, we have been engaged for the last three months.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: For the last three months?

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Yes, it will be exactly three months on Thursday.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: But how did we become engaged?

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Well, ever since dear Uncle Jack first confessed to us that he had a younger brother who was very wicked and bad, you of course have formed the chief topic of conversation between myself and Miss Prism. And of course a man who is much talked about is always very attractive. One feels there must be something in him after all. I daresay it was foolish of me, but I fell in love with you, Ernest.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Darling! And when was the engagement actually settled?

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: On the 14th of February last. Worn out by your entire ignorance of my existence, I determined to end the matter one way or the other, and after a long struggle with myself I accepted you under this dear old tree here. The next day I bought this little ring in your name, and this is the little bangle with the true lovers’ knot I promised you always to wear.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Did I give you this? It’s very pretty, isn’t it?

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Yes, you’ve wonderfully good taste, Ernest. It’s the excuse I’ve always given for your leading such a bad life. And this is the box in which I keep all your dear letters. [Kneels at table, opens box, and produces letters tied up with blue ribbon.]>

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: My letters! But my own sweet Cecily, I have never written you any letters.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: You need hardly remind me of that, Ernest. I remember only too well that I was forced to write your letters for you. I wrote always three times a week, and sometimes oftener.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Oh, do let me read them, Cecily?

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Oh, I couldn’t possibly. They would make you far too conceited. [Replaces box.] The three you wrote me after I had broken off the engagement are so beautiful, and so badly spelled, that even now I can hardly read them without crying a little.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: But was our engagement ever broken off?

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Of course it was. On the 22nd of last March. You can see the entry if you like. [Shows diary.]

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: “To-day I broke off my engagement with Ernest. I feel it is better to do so. The weather still continues charming."

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: But why on earth did you break it off? What had I done? I had done nothing at all. Cecily, I am very much hurt indeed to hear you broke it off. Particularly when the weather was so charming.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: It would hardly have been a really serious engagement if it hadn’t been broken off at least once. But I forgave you before the week was out.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: [Crossing to her, and kneeling.] What a perfect angel you are, Cecily.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: You dear romantic boy. [He kisses her, she puts her fingers through his hair.] I hope your hair curls naturally, does it?

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Yes, darling, with a little help from others.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: I am so glad.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: You’ll never break off our engagement again, Cecily?

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: I don’t think I could break it off now that I have actually met you. Besides, of course, there is the question of your name.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Yes, of course. [Nervously.]

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: You must not laugh at me, darling, but it had always been a girlish dream of mine to love some one whose name was Ernest. [Algernon rises, Cecily also.] There is something in that name that seems to inspire absolute confidence. I pity any poor married woman whose husband is not called Ernest.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: But, my dear child, do you mean to say you could not love me if I had some other name?

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: But what name?

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Oh, any name you like--Algernon--for instance . . .

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: But I don’t like the name of Algernon.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Well, my own dear, sweet, loving little darling, I really can’t see why you should object to the name of Algernon. It is not at all a bad name. In fact, it is rather an aristocratic name. Half of the chaps who get into the Bankruptcy Court are called Algernon. But seriously, Cecily . . . [Moving to her] . . . if my name was Algy, couldn’t you love me?
