sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: [Rising.] I might respect you, Ernest, I might admire your character, but I fear that I should not be able to give you my undivided attention.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Ahem! Cecily! [Picking up hat.] Your Rector here is, I suppose, thoroughly experienced in the practice of all the rites and ceremonials of the Church?

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Oh yes. Dr. Chasuble is a most learned man. He has never written a single book, so you can imagine how much he knows.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: I must see him at once on a most important christening--I mean on most important business.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: I shan’t be away more than half an hour.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Considering that we have been engaged since February the 14th, and that I only met you to-day for the first time, I think it is rather hard that you should leave me for so long a period as half an hour. Couldn’t you make it twenty minutes?

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: I’ll be back in no time. [Kisses her and rushes down the garden.]

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: What an impetuous boy he is! I like his hair so much. I must enter his proposal in my diary.

sp.speaker: MERRIMAN
sp.l: A Miss Fairfax has just called to see Mr. Worthing. On very important business Miss Fairfax states.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Isn’t Mr. Worthing in his library?

sp.speaker: MERRIMAN
sp.l: Mr. Worthing went over in the direction of the Rectory some time ago.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Pray ask the lady to come out here; Mr. Worthing is sure to be back soon. And you can bring tea.

sp.speaker: MERRIMAN
sp.l: Yes, Miss. [Goes out.]

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Miss Fairfax! I suppose one of the many good elderly women who are associated with Uncle Jack in some of his philanthropic work in London. I don’t quite like women who are interested in philanthropic work. I think it is so forward of them.

sp.speaker: MERRIMAN
sp.l: Miss Fairfax.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: [Advancing to meet her.] Pray let me introduce myself to you. My name is Cecily Cardew.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Cecily Cardew? [Moving to her and shaking hands.] What a very sweet name! Something tells me that we are going to be great friends. I like you already more than I can say. My first impressions of people are never wrong.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: How nice of you to like me so much after we have known each other such a comparatively short time. Pray sit down.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: [Still standing up.] I may call you Cecily, may I not?

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: With pleasure!

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: And you will always call me Gwendolen, won’t you.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: If you wish.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Then that is all quite settled, is it not?

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: I hope so. [A pause. They both sit down together.]

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Perhaps this might be a favourable opportunity for my mentioning who I am. My father is Lord Bracknell. You have never heard of papa, I suppose?

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: I don’t think so.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Outside the family circle, papa, I am glad to say, is entirely unknown. I think that is quite as it should be. The home seems to me to be the proper sphere for the man. And certainly once a man begins to neglect his domestic duties he becomes painfully effeminate, does he not? And I don’t like that. It makes men so very attractive. Cecily, mamma, whose views on education are remarkably strict, has brought me up to be extremely short-sighted; it is part of her system; so do you mind my looking at you through my glasses?

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Oh! not at all, Gwendolen. I am very fond of being looked at.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: [After examining Cecily carefully through a lorgnette.] You are here on a short visit I suppose.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Oh no! I live here.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: [Severely.] Really? Your mother, no doubt, or some female relative of advanced years, resides here also?

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Oh no! I have no mother, nor, in fact, any relations.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Indeed?

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: My dear guardian, with the assistance of Miss Prism, has the arduous task of looking after me.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Your guardian?

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Yes, I am Mr. Worthing’s ward.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l:
Oh! It is strange he never mentioned to me that he had a ward. How secretive of him! He grows more interesting hourly. I am not sure, however, that the news inspires me with feelings of
unmixed delight. [Rising and going to her.] I am very fond of you, Cecily; I have liked you ever since I met you! But I am bound to state that now that I know that you are Mr. Worthing’s ward, I cannot help expressing a wish you were--well just a little older than you seem to be--and not quite so very alluring in appearance. In fact, if I may speak candidly--

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Pray do! I think that whenever one has anything unpleasant to say, one should always be quite candid.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Well, to speak with perfect candour, Cecily, I wish that you were fully forty-two, and more than usually plain for your age. Ernest has a strong upright nature. He is the very soul of truth and honour. Disloyalty would be as impossible to him as deception. But even men of the noblest possible moral character are extremely susceptible to the influence of the physical charms of others. Modern, no less than Ancient History, supplies us with many most painful examples of what I refer to. If it were not so, indeed, History would be quite unreadable.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: I beg your pardon, Gwendolen, did you say Ernest?

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Oh, but it is not Mr. Ernest Worthing who is my guardian. It is his brother--his elder brother.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Ernest never mentioned to me that he had a brother.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: I am sorry to say they have not been on good terms for a long time.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Ah! that accounts for it. And now that I think of it I have never heard any man mention his brother. The subject seems distasteful to most men. Cecily, you have lifted a load from my mind. I was growing almost anxious. It would have been terrible if any cloud had come across a friendship like ours, would it not? Of course you are quite, quite sure that it is not Mr. Ernest Worthing who is your guardian?

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Quite sure. [A pause.] In fact, I am going to be his.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: I beg your pardon?

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Dearest Gwendolen, there is no reason why I should make a secret of it to you. Our little county newspaper is sure to chronicle the fact next week. Mr. Ernest Worthing and I are engaged to be married.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: My darling Cecily, I think there must be some slight error. Mr. Ernest Worthing is engaged to me. The announcement will appear in the “Morning Post” on Saturday at the latest.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: I am afraid you must be under some misconception. Ernest proposed to me exactly ten minutes ago. [Shows diary.]

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: It is certainly very curious, for he asked me to be his wife yesterday afternoon at 5.30. If you would care to verify the incident, pray do so. [Produces diary of her own.] I never travel without my diary. One should always have something sensational to read in the train. I am so sorry, dear Cecily, if it is any disappointment to you, but I am afraid I have the prior claim.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: It would distress me more than I can tell you, dear Gwendolen, if it caused you any mental or physical anguish, but I feel bound to point out that since Ernest proposed to you he clearly has changed his mind.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: If the poor fellow has been entrapped into any foolish promise I shall consider it my duty to rescue him at once, and with a firm hand.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Whatever unfortunate entanglement my dear boy may have got into, I will never reproach him with it after we are married.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Do you allude to me, Miss Cardew, as an entanglement? You are presumptuous. On an occasion of this kind it becomes more than a moral duty to speak one’s mind. It becomes a pleasure.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Do you suggest, Miss Fairfax, that I entrapped Ernest into an engagement? How dare you? This is no time for wearing the shallow mask of manners. When I see a spade I call it a spade.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: I am glad to say that I have never seen a spade. It is obvious that our social spheres have been widely different.

div.stage: [Enter Merriman, followed by the footman. He carries a salver, table cloth, and plate stand. Cecily is about to retort. The presence of the servants exercises a restraining influence, under which both girls chafe.]

sp.speaker: MERRIMAN
sp.l: Shall I lay tea here as usual, Miss?

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Yes, as usual.

div.stage: [Merriman begins to clear table and lay cloth. A long pause. Cecily and Gwendolen glare at each other.]

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Are there many interesting walks in the vicinity, Miss Cardew?

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Oh! yes! a great many. From the top of one of the hills quite close one can see five counties.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Five counties! I don’t think I should like that. I hate crowds.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: I suppose that is why you live in town?
sp.stage: [Gwendolen bites her lip, and beats her foot nervously with her parasol.]

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Quite a well-kept garden this is, Miss Cardew.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: So glad you like it, Miss Fairfax.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: I had no idea there were any flowers in the country.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Oh, flowers are as common here, Miss Fairfax, as people are in London.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Personally I cannot understand how anybody manages to exist in the country, if anybody who is anybody does. The country always bores me to death.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l:
Ah! This is what the newspapers call agricultural depression, is it not? I believe the aristocracy are suffering very much from it just at present. It
is almost an epidemic amongst them, I have been told. May I offer you some tea, Miss Fairfax?

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Thank you. [Aside.] Detestable girl! But I require tea!

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Sugar?

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: No, thank you. Sugar is not fashionable any more.
sp.stage: [Cecily looks angrily at her, takes up the tongs and puts four lumps of sugar into the cup.]

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: [Severely.] Cake or bread and butter?

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: [In a bored manner.] Bread and butter, please. Cake is rarely seen at the best houses nowadays.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: [Cuts a very large slice of cake, and puts it on the tray.] Hand that to Miss Fairfax.

div.stage: [Merriman does so, and goes out with footman. Gwendolen drinks the tea and makes a grimace. Puts down cup at once, reaches out her hand to the bread and butter, looks at it, and finds it is cake. Rises in indignation.]

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: You have filled my tea with lumps of sugar, and though I asked most distinctly for bread and butter, you have given me cake. I am known for the gentleness of my disposition, and the extraordinary sweetness of my nature, but I warn you, Miss Cardew, you may go too far.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: To save my poor, innocent, trusting boy from the machinations of any other girl there are no lengths to which I would not go.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: From the moment I saw you I distrusted you. I felt that you were false and deceitful. I am never deceived in such matters. My first impressions of people are invariably right.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: It seems to me, Miss Fairfax, that I am trespassing on your valuable time. No doubt you have many other calls of a similar character to make in the neighbourhood.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Ernest! My own Ernest!

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Gwendolen! Darling! [Offers to kiss her.]

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: A moment! May I ask if you are engaged to be married to this young lady? [Points to Cecily.]

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: To dear little Cecily! Of course not! What could have put such an idea into your pretty little head?

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Thank you. You may!

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: I knew there must be some misunderstanding, Miss Fairfax. The gentleman whose arm is at present round your waist is my dear guardian, Mr. John Worthing.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: I beg your pardon?

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: This is Uncle Jack.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Jack! Oh!

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Here is Ernest.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.stage: [Goes straight over to Cecily without noticing anyone else.]
sp.l: My own love! [Offers to kiss her.]

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: A moment, Ernest! May I ask you--are you engaged to be married to this young lady?

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: To what young lady? Good heavens! Gwendolen!

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Yes! to good heavens, Gwendolen, I mean to Gwendolen.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Of course not! What could have put such an idea into your pretty little head?

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Thank you.
You may.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: I felt there was some slight error, Miss Cardew. The gentleman who is now embracing you is my cousin, Mr. Algernon Moncrieff.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Algernon Moncrieff! Oh!
sp.stage: [The two girls move towards each other and put their arms round each other's waists as if for protection.]

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Are you called Algernon?

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: I cannot deny it.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Is your name really John?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: I could deny it if I liked. I could deny anything if I liked. But my name certainly is John. It has been John for years.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: A gross deception has been practised on both of us.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: My poor wounded Cecily!

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: My sweet wronged Gwendolen!

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: You will call me sister, will you not?
sp.stage: [They embrace. Jack and Algernon groan and walk up and down.]

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: There is just one question I would like to be allowed to ask my guardian.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: An admirable idea! Mr. Worthing, there is just one question I would like to be permitted to put to you. Where is your brother Ernest? We are both engaged to be married to your brother Ernest, so it is a matter of some importance to us to know where your brother Ernest is at present.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l:
Gwendolen--Cecily
--it is very painful for me to be forced to speak the truth. It is the first time in my life that I have ever been reduced to such a painful position, and I am really quite inexperienced in doing anything of the kind. However I will tell you quite frankly that I have no brother Ernest. I have no brother at all. I never had a brother in my life, and I certainly have not the smallest intention of ever having one in the future.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: No brother at all?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: None!

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Had you never a brother of any kind?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Never. Not even of any kind.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: I am afraid it is quite clear, Cecily, that neither of us is engaged to be married to anyone.
sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: It is not a very pleasant position for a young girl suddenly to find herself in. Is it?

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Let us go into the house. They will hardly venture to come after us there.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: No, men are so cowardly, aren’t they?

div.stage: [They retire into the house with scornful looks.]

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: This ghastly state of things is what you call Bunburying, I suppose?

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Yes, and a perfectly wonderful Bunbury it is. The most wonderful Bunbury I have ever had in my life.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Well, you’ve no right whatsoever to Bunbury here.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: That is absurd. One has a right to Bunbury anywhere one chooses. Every serious Bunburyist knows that.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Serious Bunburyist! Good heavens!

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Well, one must be serious about something, if one wants to have any amusement in life. I happen to be serious about Bunburying. What on earth you are serious about I haven’t got the remotest idea. About everything, I should fancy. You have such an absolutely trivial nature.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Well, the only small satisfaction I have in the whole of this wretched business is that your friend Bunbury is quite exploded. You won’t be able to run down to the country quite so often as you used to do, dear Algy. And a very good thing too.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Your brother is a little off colour, isn’t he, dear Jack? You won’t be able to disappear to London quite so frequently as your wicked custom was. And not a bad thing either.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: As for your conduct towards Miss Cardew, I must say that your taking in a sweet, simple, innocent girl like that is quite inexcusable. To say nothing of the fact that she is my ward.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: I can see no possible defence at all for your deceiving a brilliant, clever, thoroughly experienced
young lady like Miss Fairfax. To say nothing of the fact that she is my cousin.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: I wanted to be engaged to Gwendolen, that is all. I love her.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Well, I simply wanted to be engaged to Cecily. I adore her.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: There is certainly no chance of your marrying Miss Cardew.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: I don’t think there is much likelihood, Jack, of you and Miss Fairfax being united.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Well, that is no business of yours.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: If it was my business, I wouldn’t talk about it. [Begins to eat muffins.] It is very vulgar to talk about one’s business. Only people like stockbroker’s do that, and then merely at dinner parties.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: How can you sit there, calmly eating muffins when
we are in this horrible trouble, I can’t make out. You seem to me to be perfectly heartless.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Well, I can’t eat muffins in an agitated manner. The butter would probably get on my cuffs. One should always eat muffins quite calmly. It is the only way to eat them.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: I say it’s perfectly heartless your eating muffins at all, under the circumstances.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: When I am in trouble, eating is the only thing that consoles me. Indeed, when I am in really great trouble, as anyone who knows me intimately will tell you, I refuse everything except food and drink. At the present moment I am eating muffins because I am unhappy. Besides, I am particularly fond of muffins. [Rising.]

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: [Rising.] Well, that is no reason why you should eat them all in that greedy way. [Takes muffins from Algernon.]

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: [Offering tea-cake.] I wish you would have tea-cake instead. I don’t like tea-cake.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Good heavens! I suppose a man may eat his own muffins in his own garden.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: But you have just said it was perfectly heartless to eat muffins.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: I said it was perfectly heartless of you, under the circumstances. That is a very different thing.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: That may be. But the muffins are the same. [He seizes the muffin-dish from Jack.]

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Algy, I wish to goodness you would go.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: You can’t possibly ask me to go without having some dinner. It’s absurd. I never go without my dinner. No one ever does, except vegetarians and people like that. Besides I have just made arrangements with Dr. Chasuble to be christened at a quarter to six under the name of Ernest.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: My dear fellow, the sooner you give up that nonsense the better. I made arrangements this morning with Dr. Chasuble to be christened myself at 5.30, and I naturally will take the name of Ernest. Gwendolen would wish it. We can’t both be christened Ernest. It’s absurd. Besides, I have a perfect right to be christened if I like. There is no evidence at all that I ever have been christened by anybody. I should think it extremely probable I never was, and so does Dr. Chasuble. It is entirely different in your case. You have been christened already.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Yes, but I have not been christened for years.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Yes, but you have been christened. That is the important thing.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Quite so. So I know my constitution can stand it. If you are not quite sure about your ever having been christened, I must say I think it rather dangerous your venturing on it now. It might make you very unwell. You can hardly have forgotten that someone very closely connected with you was very nearly carried off this week in Paris by a severe chill.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Yes, but you said yourself that a severe chill was not hereditary.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: It usen’t to be, I know--but I daresay it is now. Science is always making wonderful improvements in things.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: [Picking up the muffin-dish.] Oh, that is nonsense; you are always talking nonsense.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Jack, you are at the muffins again! I wish you wouldn’t. There are only two left. [Takes them.] I told you I was particularly fond of muffins.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: But I hate tea-cake.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Why on earth then do you allow tea-cake to be served up for your guests? What ideas you have of hospitality!

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Algernon! I have already told you to go. I don’t want you here. Why don’t you go!

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: I haven’t quite finished my tea yet! and there is still one muffin left. [Jack groans, and sinks into a chair. Algernon still continues eating.]

div.stage: [Gwendolen and Cecily are at the window, looking out into the garden.]

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: The fact that they did not follow us at once into the house, as anyone else would have done, seems to me to show that they have some sense of shame left.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: They have been eating muffins. That looks like repentance.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: [After a pause.] They don’t seem to notice us at all. Couldn’t you cough?

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: But I haven’t got a cough.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: They’re looking at us. What effrontery!

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: They’re approaching. That’s very forward of them.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Let us preserve a dignified silence.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Certainly. It’s the only thing to do now.

div.stage: [Enter Jack followed by Algernon. They whistle some dreadful popular air from a British Opera.]

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: This dignified silence seems to produce an unpleasant effect.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: A most distasteful one.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: But we will not be the first to speak.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Certainly not.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Mr. Worthing, I have something very particular to ask you. Much depends on your reply.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Gwendolen, your common sense is invaluable. Mr. Moncrieff, kindly answer me the following question. Why did you pretend to be my guardian’s brother?

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: In order that I might have an opportunity of meeting you.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: That certainly seems a satisfactory explanation, does it not?

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Yes, dear, if you can believe him.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: I don’t. But that does not affect the wonderful beauty of his answer.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: True. In matters of grave importance, style, not sincerity is the vital thing. Mr. Worthing, what explanation can you offer to me for pretending to have a brother? Was it in order that you might have an opportunity of coming up to town to see me as often as possible?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Can you doubt it, Miss Fairfax?

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: I have the gravest doubts upon the subject. But I intend to crush them. This is not the moment for German scepticism. [Moving to Cecily.] Their explanations appear to be quite satisfactory, especially Mr. Worthing’s. That seems to me to have the stamp of truth upon it.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: I am more than content with what Mr. Moncrieff said. His voice alone inspires one with absolute credulity.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Then you think we should forgive them?

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Yes. I mean no.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: True! I had forgotten. There are principles at stake that one cannot surrender. Which of us should tell them? The task is not a pleasant one.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Could we not both speak at the same time?

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: An excellent idea! I nearly always speak at the same time as other people. Will you take the time from me?

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Certainly.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN and CECILY
sp.l: Your Christian names are still an insuperable barrier. That is all!

sp.speaker: JACK and ALGERNON
sp.l: Our Christian names! Is that all? But we are going to be christened this afternoon.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: For my sake you are prepared to do this terrible thing?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: I am.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: To please me you are ready to face this fearful ordeal?

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: I am!

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l:
How absurd to talk of the equality of the sexes!
Where questions of self-sacrifice are concerned, men are infinitely beyond us.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: We are.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: They have moments of physical courage of which we women know absolutely nothing.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Darling!

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Darling!

div.stage: [Enter Merriman. When he enters he coughs loudly, seeing the situation.]

sp.speaker: MERRIMAN
sp.l: Ahem! Ahem! Lady Bracknell!

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Good heavens!

div.stage: [Enter Lady Bracknell. The couples separate in alarm. Exit Merriman.]

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: Gwendolen! What does this mean?

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Merely that I am engaged to be married to Mr. Worthing, mamma.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: Come here. Sit down. Sit down immediately. Hesitation of any kind is a sign of mental decay in the young, of physical weakness in the old. [Turns to Jack.] Apprised, sir, of my daughter's sudden flight by her trusty maid, whose confidence I purchased by means of a small coin, I followed her at once by a luggage train. Her unhappy father is, I am glad to say, under the impression that she is attending a more than usually lengthy lecture by the University Extension Scheme on the Influence of a permanent income on Thought. I do not propose to undeceive him. Indeed I have never undeceived him on any question. I would consider it wrong. But of course, you will clearly understand that all communication between yourself and my daughter must cease immediately from this moment. On this point, as indeed on all points, I am firm.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: I am engaged to be married to Gwendolen, Lady Bracknell!

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: You are nothing of the kind, sir. And now, as regards Algernon! . . . Algernon!

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Yes, Aunt Augusta.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: May I ask if it is in this house that your invalid friend Mr. Bunbury resides?

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Oh! No! Bunbury doesn’t live here. Bunbury is somewhere else at present. In fact, Bunbury is dead.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: Dead! When did Mr. Bunbury die? His death must have been extremely sudden.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Oh! I killed Bunbury this afternoon. I mean poor Bunbury died this afternoon.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: What did he die of?

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Bunbury? Oh, he was quite exploded.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l:
Exploded! Was he the victim of a revolutionary outrage? I was not aware that Mr. Bunbury was
interested in social legislation. If so, he is well punished for his morbidity.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: My dear Aunt Augusta, I mean he was found out! The doctors found out that Bunbury could not live, that is what I mean--so Bunbury died.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: He seems to have had great confidence in the opinion of his physicians. I am glad, however, that he made up his mind at the last to some definite course of action, and acted under proper medical advice. And now that we have finally got rid of this Mr. Bunbury, may I ask, Mr. Worthing, who is that young person whose hand my nephew Algernon is now holding in what seems to me a peculiarly unnecessary manner?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: That lady is Miss Cecily Cardew, my ward.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: I am engaged to be married to Cecily, Aunt Augusta.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: I beg your pardon?

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Mr. Moncrieff and I are engaged to be married, Lady Bracknell.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: [With a shiver, crossing to the sofa and sitting down.] I do not know whether there is anything peculiarly exciting in the air of this particular part of Hertfordshire, but the number of engagements that go on seems to me considerably above the proper average that statistics have laid down for our guidance. I think some preliminary enquiry on my part would not be out of place. Mr. Worthing, is Miss Cardew at all connected with any of the larger railway stations in London? I merely desire information. Until yesterday I had no idea that there were any families or persons whose origin was a Terminus. [Jack looks perfectly furious, but restrains himself.]

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: [In a clear, cold voice.] Miss Cardew is the granddaughter of the late Mr. Thomas Cardew of 149, Belgrave Square, S.W.; Gervase Park, Dorking, Surrey; and the Sporran, Fifeshire, N.B.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: That sounds not unsatisfactory. Three addresses always inspire confidence, even in tradesmen. But what proof have I of their authenticity?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: I have carefully preserved the Court Guides of the period. They are open to your inspection, Lady Bracknell.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: [Grimly.] I have known strange errors in that publication.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Miss Cardew's family solicitors are Messrs. Markby, Markby, and Markby.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: Markby, Markby, and Markby? A firm of the very highest position in their profession. Indeed I am told that one of the Mr. Markbys is occasionally to be seen at dinner parties. So far I am satisfied.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: [Very irritably.] How extremely kind of you, Lady Bracknell! I have also in my possession, you will be pleased to hear, certificates of Miss Cardew's birth, baptism, whooping cough, registration, vaccination, confirmation, and the measles; both the German and the English variety.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l:
Ah! A life crowded with incident, I see; though
perhaps somewhat too exciting for a young girl. I am not myself in favour of premature experiences. [Rises, looks at her watch.] Gwendolen! the time approaches for our departure. We have not a moment to lose. As a matter of form, Mr. Worthing, I had better ask you if Miss Cardew has any little fortune?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Oh! about a hundred and thirty thousand pounds in the Funds. That is all. Good-bye, Lady Bracknell. So pleased to have seen you.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: [Sitting down again.] A moment, Mr. Worthing. A hundred and thirty thousand pounds! And in the Funds! Miss Cardew seems to me a most attractive young lady, now that I look at her. Few girls of the present day have any really solid qualities, any of the qualities that last, and improve with time. We live, I regret to say, in an age of surfaces. [To Cecily.] Come over here, dear. [Cecily goes across.] Pretty child! your dress is sadly simple, and your hair seems almost as Nature might have left it. But we can soon alter all that. A thoroughly experienced French maid produces a really marvellous result in a very brief space of time. I remember recommending one to young Lady Lancing, and after three months her own husband did not know her.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: [Aside.] And after six months nobody knew her

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: [Glares at Jack for a few moments. Then bends, with a practised smile, to Cecily.] Kindly turn round, sweet child. [Cecily turns completely round.] No, the side view is what I want. [Cecily presents her profile.] Yes, quite as I expected. There are distinct social possibilities in your profile. The two weak points in our age are its want of principle and its want of profile. The chin a little higher, dear. Style largely depends on the way the chin is worn. They are worn very high, just at present. Algernon!

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Yes, Aunt Augusta!

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: There are distinct social possibilities in Miss Cardew's profile.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Cecily is the sweetest, dearest, prettiest girl in the whole world. And I don't care twopence about social possibilities.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l:
Never speak disrespectfully of Society, Algernon. Only people who can't get into it do that. [To Cecily.] Dear child, of course you know that Algernon has nothing but his debts to depend upon. But I do not approve of mercenary marriages.
When I married Lord Bracknell I had no fortune of any kind. But I never dreamed for a moment of allowing that to stand in my way. Well, I suppose I must give my consent.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Thank you, Aunt Augusta.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: Cecily, you may kiss me!

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: [Kisses her.] Thank you, Lady Bracknell.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: You may also address me as Aunt Augusta for the future.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Thank you, Aunt Augusta.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: The marriage, I think, had better take place quite soon.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Thank you, Aunt Augusta.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Thank you, Aunt Augusta.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: To speak frankly, I am not in favour of long engagements. They give people the opportunity of finding out each other's character before marriage, which I think is never advisable.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: I beg your pardon for interrupting you, Lady Bracknell, but this engagement is quite out of the question. I am Miss Cardew's guardian, and she cannot marry without my consent until she comes of age. That consent I absolutely decline to give.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: Upon what grounds may I ask? Algernon is an extremely, I may almost say an ostentatiously, eligible young man. He has nothing, but he looks everything. What more can one desire?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: It pains me very much to have to speak frankly to you, Lady Bracknell, about your nephew, but the fact is that I do not approve at all of his moral character. I suspect him of being untruthful. [Algernon and Cecily look at him in indignant amazement.]

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: Untruthful! My nephew Algernon? Impossible! He is an Oxonian.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: I fear there can be no possible doubt about the matter. This afternoon, during my temporary absence in London on an important question of romance, he obtained admission to my house by means of the false pretence of being my brother. Under an assumed name he drank, I’ve just been informed by my butler, an entire pint bottle of my Perrier-Jouet, Brut, ’89; a wine I was specially reserving for myself. Continuing his disgraceful deception, he succeeded in the course of the afternoon in alienating the affections of my only ward. He subsequently stayed to tea, and devoured every single muffin. And what makes his conduct all the more heartless is, that he was perfectly well aware from the first that I have no brother, that I never had a brother, and that I don’t intend to have a brother, not even of any kind. I distinctly told him so myself yesterday afternoon.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: Ahem! Mr. Worthing, after careful consideration I have decided entirely to overlook my nephew’s conduct to you.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l:
That is very generous of you, Lady Bracknell.
My own decision, however, is unalterable. I decline to give my consent.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: [To Cecily.] Come here, sweet child. [Cecily goes over.] How old are you, dear?

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Well, I am really only eighteen, but I always admit to twenty when I go to evening parties.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: You are perfectly right in making some slight alteration. Indeed, no woman should ever be quite accurate about her age. It looks so calculating. [In a meditative manner.] Eighteen, but admitting to twenty at evening parties. Well, it will not be very long before you are of age and free from the restraints of tutelage. So I don’t think your guardian’s consent is, after all, a matter of any importance.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Pray excuse me, Lady Bracknell, for interrupting you again, but it is only fair to tell you that according to the terms of her grandfather’s will Miss Cardew does not come legally of age till she is thirty-five.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: That does not seem to me to be a grave objection. Thirty-five is a very attractive age. London society is full of women of the very highest birth who have, of their own free choice, remained thirty-five for years. Lady Dumbleton is an instance in point. To my own knowledge she has been thirty-five ever since she arrived at the age of forty, which was many years ago now. I see no reason why our dear Cecily should not be even still more attractive at the age you mention than she is at present. There will be a large accumulation of property.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Algy, could you wait for me till I was thirty-five?

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Of course I could, Cecily. You know I could.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Yes, I felt it instinctively, but I couldn’t wait all that time. I hate waiting even five minutes for anybody. It always makes me rather cross. I am not punctual myself, I know, but I do like punctuality in others, and waiting, even to be married, is quite out of the question.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Then what is to be done, Cecily?

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: I don’t know, Mr. Moncrieff.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: My dear Mr. Worthing, as Miss Cardew states positively that she cannot wait till she is thirty-five--a remark which I am bound to say seems to me to show a somewhat impatient nature--I would beg of you to reconsider your decision.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: But my dear Lady Bracknell, the matter is entirely in your own hands. The moment you consent to my marriage with Gwendolen, I will most gladly allow your nephew to form an alliance with my ward.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: [Rising and drawing herself up.] You must be quite aware that what you propose is out of the question.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Then a passionate celibacy is all that any of us can look forward to.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l:
That is not the destiny I propose for Gwendolen. Algernon, of course, can choose for himself. [Pulls out her watch.] Come, dear; [Gwendolen rises] we have already missed five, if not six, trains. To
miss any more might expose us to comment on the platform.

div.l: miss any more might expose us to comment on the platform.

sp.speaker: CHASUBLE
sp.l: Everything is quite ready for the christenings.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: The christenings, sir! Is not that somewhat premature?

sp.speaker: CHASUBLE
sp.l: [Looking rather puzzled, and pointing to Jack and Algernon.] Both these gentlemen have expressed a desire for immediate baptism.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: At their age? The idea is grotesque and irreligious! Algernon, I forbid you to be baptised. I will not hear of such excesses. Lord Bracknell would be highly displeased if he learned that that was the way in which you wasted your time and money.

sp.speaker: CHASUBLE
sp.l: Am I to understand then that there are to be no christenings at all this afternoon?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: I don’t think that, as things are now, it would be of much practical value to either of us, Dr. Chasuble.

sp.speaker: CHASUBLE
sp.l: I am grieved to hear such sentiments from you, Mr. Worthing. They savour of the heretical views of the Anabaptists, views that I have completely refuted in four of my unpublished sermons. However, as your present mood seems to be one peculiarly secular, I will return to the church at once. Indeed, I have just been informed by the pew-opener that for the last hour and a half Miss Prism has been waiting for me in the vestry.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: [Starting.] Miss Prism! Did I hear you mention a Miss Prism?

sp.speaker: CHASUBLE
sp.l: Yes, Lady Bracknell. I am on my way to join her.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: Pray allow me to detain you for a moment. This matter may prove to be one of vital importance to Lord Bracknell and myself. Is this Miss Prism a female of repellent aspect, remotely connected with education?

sp.speaker: CHASUBLE
sp.l: [Somewhat indignantly.] She is the most cultivated of ladies, and the very picture of respectability.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: It is obviously the same person. May I ask what position she holds in your household?

sp.speaker: CHASUBLE
sp.l: [Severely.] I am a celibate, madam.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: [Interposing.]Miss Prism, Lady Bracknell, has been for the last three years Miss Cardew's esteemed governess and valued companion.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: In spite of what I hear of her, I must see her at once. Let her be sent for.

sp.speaker: CHASUBLE
sp.l: [Looking off.] She approaches; she is nigh.

sp.speaker: MISS PRISM
sp.l: I was told you expected me in the vestry, dear Canon. I have been waiting for you there for an hour and three quarters. [Catches sight of Lady Bracknell who has fixed her with a stony glare. Miss Prism grows pale and quails. She looks anxiously round as if desirous to escape.]

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: [In a severe, judicial voice.] Prism! [Miss Prism bows her head in shame.] Come here, Prism! [Miss Prism approaches in a humble manner.] Prism! Where is that baby? [General consternation. The Canon starts back in horror. Algernon and Jack pretend to be anxious to shield Cecily and Gwendolen from hearing the details of a terrible public scandal.] Twenty eight years ago, Prism, you left Lord Bracknell's house, Number 104, Upper Grosvenor Street, in charge of a perambulator that contained a baby, of the male sex. You never returned. A few weeks later, through the elaborate investigations of the Metropolitan police, the perambulator was discovered at midnight, standing by itself in a remote corner of Bayswater. It contained the manuscript of a three-volume novel of more than usually revolting sentimentality. [Miss Prism starts in involuntary indignation.] But the baby was not there! [Everyone looks at Miss Prism.] Prism! Where is that baby? [A pause.]

Lady Bracknell, I admit with shame that I do not know. I only wish I did. The plain facts of the case are these. On the morning of the day you mention, a day that is for ever branded on my memory, I prepared as usual to take the baby out in its perambulator. I had also with me a somewhat old, but capacious hand-bag in which I had intended to place the manuscript of a work of fiction that I had written during my few unoccupied hours.
In a moment of mental abstraction, for which I never can forgive myself, I deposited the manuscript in the bassinette, and placed the baby in the hand-bag.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: [Who has been listening attentively.] But where did you deposit the hand-bag?

sp.speaker: MISS PRISM
sp.l: Do not ask me, Mr. Worthing.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Miss Prism, this is a matter of no small importance to me. I insist on knowing where you deposited the hand-bag that contained that infant.

sp.speaker: MISS PRISM
sp.l: I left it in the cloak room of one of the larger railway stations in London.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: What railway station?

sp.speaker: MISS PRISM
sp.l: [Quite crushed.] Victoria. The Brighton line. [Sinks into a chair.]

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: I must retire to my room for a moment. Gwendolen, wait here for me.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: If you are not too long, I will wait here for you all my life.

sp.speaker: CHASUBLE
sp.l: What do you think this means, Lady Bracknell?

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: I dare not even suspect, Dr. Chasuble. I need hardly tell you that in families of high position strange coincidences are not supposed to occur. They are hardly considered the thing.
sp.stage: [Voices heard overhead as if someone was throwing trunks about. Everyone looks up.]

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: Uncle Jack seems strangely agitated.

sp.speaker: CHASUBLE
sp.l: Your guardian has a very emotional nature.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: This noise is extremely unpleasant. It sounds as if he was having an argument. I dislike arguments of any kind. They are always vulgar, and often convincing.

sp.speaker: CHASUBLE
sp.l: [Looking up.] It has stopped now. [The noise is redoubled.]

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: I wish he would arrive at some conclusion.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: This suspense is terrible. I hope it will last.

div.stage: [Enter Jack with a hand-bag of black leather in his hand.]

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: [Rushing over to Miss Prism.] Is this the hand-bag, Miss Prism? Examine it carefully before you speak. The happiness of more than one life depends on your answer.

sp.speaker: MISS PRISM
sp.l: [Calmly.] It seems to be mine. Yes, here is the injury it received through the upsetting of a Gower Street omnibus in younger and happier days. Here is the stain on the lining caused by the explosion of a temperance beverage, an incident that occurred at Leamington. And here, on the lock, are my initials. I had forgotten that in an extravagant mood I had had them placed there. The bag is undoubtedly mine. I am delighted to have it so unexpectedly restored to me. It has been a great inconvenience being without it all these years.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: [In a pathetic voice.] Miss Prism, more is restored to you than this hand-bag. I was the baby you placed in it.

sp.speaker: MISS PRISM
sp.l: [Amazed.] You?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: [Embracing her.] Yes . . . mother!

sp.speaker: MISS PRISM
sp.l: [Recoiling in indignant astonishment.] Mr. Worthing! I am unmarried!

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Unmarried! I do not deny that is a serious blow. But after all, who has the right to cast a stone against one who has suffered? Cannot repentance wipe out an act of folly? Why should there be one law for men, and another for women? Mother, I forgive you. [Tries to embrace her again.]

sp.speaker: MISS PRISM
sp.l: [Still more indignant.] Mr. Worthing, there is some error. [Pointing to Lady Bracknell.] There is the lady who can tell you who you really are.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: [After a pause.] Lady Bracknell, I hate to seem
inquisitive, but would you kindly inform me who I am?

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: I am afraid that the news I have to give you will not altogether please you. You are the son of my poor sister, Mrs. Moncrieff, and consequently Algernon’s elder brother.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Algy’s elder brother! Then I have a brother after all. I knew I had a brother! I always said I had a brother! Cecily,--how could you have ever doubted that I had a brother. [Seizes hold of Algernon.] Dr. Chasuble, my unfortunate brother, Miss Prism, my unfortunate brother. Gwendolen, my unfortunate brother. Algy, you young scoundrel, you will have to treat me with more respect in the future. You have never behaved to me like a brother in all your life.

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Well, not till to-day, old boy, I admit. I did my best, however, though I was out of practice. [Shakes hands.]

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: [To Jack.] My own! But what own are you? What is your Christian name, now that you have become someone else?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Good heavens! . . . I had quite forgotten that point. Your decision on the subject of my name is irrevocable, I suppose?

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: I never change, except in my affections.

sp.speaker: CECILY
sp.l: What a noble nature you have, Gwendolen!

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Then the question had better be cleared up at once. Aunt Augusta, a moment. At the time when Miss Prism left me in the hand-bag, had I been christened already?

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: Every luxury that money could buy, including christening, had been lavished on you by your fond and doting parents.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Then I was christened! That is settled. Now, what name was I given? Let me know the worst.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: Being the eldest son you were naturally christened after your father.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: [Irritably.] Yes, but what was my father’s Christian name?

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: [Meditatively.] I cannot at the present moment recall what the General’s Christian name was. But I have no doubt he had one. He was eccentric, I admit. But only in later years. And that was the result of the Indian climate, and marriage, and indigestion, and other things of that kind.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Algy! Can’t you recollect what our father’s Christian name was?

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: My dear boy, we were never even on speaking terms. He died before I was a year old.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: His name would appear in the Army Lists of the period, I suppose, Aunt Augusta?

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: The General was essentially a man of peace, except in his domestic life. But I have no doubt his name would appear in any military directory.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l:
The Army Lists of the last forty years are here.
These delightful records should have been my constant study. [Rushes to bookcase and tears the books out.] M. Generals . . . . Mallam, Maxbohm, Magley, what ghastly names they have--Markby, Migsby, Mobbs, Moncrieff! Lieutenant 1840, Captain, Lieutenant-Colonel, Colonel, General 1869, Christian names, Ernest John. [Puts book very quietly down and speaks quite calmly.] I always told you, Gwendolen, my name was Ernest, didn’t I? Well, it is Ernest after all. I mean it naturally is Ernest.

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: Yes, I remember now that the General was called Ernest. I knew I had some particular reason for disliking the name.

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: Ernest! My own Ernest! I felt from the first that you could have no other name!

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Gwendolen, it is a terrible thing for a man to find out suddenly that all his life he has been speaking nothing but the truth. Can you forgive me?

sp.speaker: GWENDOLEN
sp.l: I can. For I feel that you are sure to change.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: My own one!

sp.speaker: CHASUBLE
sp.l: [To Miss Prism.] Laetitia! [Embraces her.]

sp.speaker: MISS PRISM
sp.l: [Enthusiastically.] Frederick! At last!

sp.speaker: ALGERNON
sp.l: Cecily! [Embraces her.] At last!

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Gwendolen! [Embraces her.] At last!

sp.speaker: LADY BRACKNELL
sp.l: My nephew, you seem to be displaying signs of triviality.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: On the contrary, Aunt Augusta, I’ve now realized for the first time in my life the vital Importance of Being Earnest.
